bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Donald B. Armstrong, August 14, 1940

div1.p: Hench seeks copies of "Health Through the Ages" and information on a film strip about Walter Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Donald B. Armstrong, August 14, 1940
div1.opener:
August 14, 1940
Dr. D. B. Armstrong
Third Vice-President
Metropolitan Life Ins. Co.
New York City
My dear Doctor Armstrong:
div1.p:
I have been asked to give an address this Fall on the conquest of
yellow fever on the occasion of the dedication of a memorial building dedicated
to Dr. Lazear, one of the four men who discovered the cause of yellow fever.
This will be at Washington and Jefferson College. In preparation for this talk,
I have made visits to the survivors of these experiments in Havana and elsewhere.
Mr. John J. Moran, of Havana, one of the first to volunteer for experimental
yellow fever, showed me two items, copies of which I should most appreciate
having. One was “HEALTH THROUGH THE AGES”, a pamphlet published by Winslow
and Hallock in 1933 and disseminated by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co.
Would it be possible for me to have two or three copies of this pamphlet?

Moran also showed me a strip of motion picture film entitled
“Metropolitan Minute Movies, Health Heroes Series, Walter Reed,” produced by
the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. I should appreciate much having a copy
of this film and in particular, some prints of the following original photographs,
those entitled “He was chairman of a commission to investigate the cause of
yellow fever”; that entitled, “Camp Lazear in Cuba was constructed for controlled
experiments”; that entitled, “J. Moran enters Side B and develops yellow fever
in four days. Men in Side A remain well, etc.”. If I could also obtain original
prints of the various photographs of Walter Reed and Mrs. Reed, and that of
Jernegan, I should like that very much. The picture right after that of Jernegan
is entitled “The house in which Experiment 2 was carried out.” Beside the house
stands a man who has been sometimes identified as Carroll, but Mr. Moran doubts
this. I wondered whether your researchers who prepared this film have any evidence
upon which this man could be identified. I certainly appreciate whatever help
you can give me in this matter.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
